Result.Abstract: Abstract Assessment practices in higher education institutions tend not to equip students well for the processes of effective learning in a learning society. Result.Title: Sustainable Assessment: Rethinking assessment for the learning society

Result.Abstract: Reflection and the promotion of reflective practice have become popular features of the design of educational programmes. This has often led to learning being more effectively facilitated. However, alongisde these positive initiatives have grown more disturbing developments under the general heading of reflection. They have involved both misconceptions of the nature of reflection which have led to instrumental or rule-following
Result.Title: Promoting reflection in professional courses: The challenge of context

Result.Abstract: Various forms of peer, collaborative or cooperative learning, particularly small group activities, are increasingly used within university courses to assist students meet a variety of learning outcomes. These include working collaboratively with others, taking responsibility for their own learning and deepening their understanding of specific course content. Result.Title: Peer Learning and Assessment

Result.Abstract: This paper raises issues concerning the relationship between student assessment and the values which academic institutions propagate. It argues that many current assessment practices are incompatible with the goals of independence, thoughtfulness and critical analysis to which most academics would subscribe; that forms of assessment which are commonplace are not consistent with the behaviour of academics in their own contributions
Result.Title: Assessment and the promotion of academic values

Result.Abstract: Student self-assessment occurs when learners make judgements about aspects of their own performance. This paper focuses on one aspect of quantitative self-assessments: the comparison of student-generated marks with those generated by teachers. Studies including such comparisons in the context of higher education courses are reviewed and the following questions are addressed: (i) do students tend to over- or under-rate themselves
Result.Title: Quantitative studies of student self-assessment in higher education: a critical analysis of findings

Result.Abstract: Assessment in higher education is commonly held to contribute to feedback to students on their learning and the certification of their achievement. The paper proposes that students need to become assessors within the context of participation in
Result.Title: Aligning assessment with long‐term learning

Result.Abstract: Much time and effort has gone into trying to demonstrate an empirical link between research activity and teaching performance. In general, the correlations between these factors have been shown to be low. This paper argues that the attempt to find such a link will always be confounded by different conceptions of the two enterprises. The debate about the relationships between
Result.Title: Teaching and research: Establishing the vital link with learning

Result.Abstract: This paper addresses the question of who is involved in learning in workplaces and the ways in which members of workgroups learn as part of their normal work. It draws on qualitative data from a study of multiple worksites with differentiated work within a large organisation. It examines the value of the notion of communities of practice in conceptualising such
Result.Title: Learning from others at work: communities of practice and informal learning

Result.Abstract: We write journals for many different reasons prompted by many different purposes. We may want to capture an experience, record an event, explore our feelings or make sense of what we know. We may want to narrate something of importance so that others can see what we saw in it. Sometimes we write primarily for ourselves, sometimes for other people.
Result.Title: Using journal writing to enhance reflective practice

Result.Abstract: Academic development should be conceptualized not only as a university‐wide process, but also as a local practice and as a process of peer learning in the workplace. Result.Title: Situating academic development in professional work: Using peer learning

Result.Title: ‘Peer learning’ as pedagogic discourse for research education

Result.Title: The Impact of Self-assessment on Achievement: The effects of self-assessment training on performance in external examinations

Result.Title: Making the most of experience

Result.Title: Writing Groups, Change and Academic Identity: Research development as local practice

Result.Title: Avoiding the traps: seeking good practice in the use of self assessment and reflection in professional courses

Result.Title: Preparing for new academic roles: An holistic approach to development

Result.Title: “I don’t think I am a learner”: acts of naming learners at work

Result.Title: Experience as the Base for Learning

Result.Title: The in‐between: exposing everyday learning at work

Result.Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to challenge models of workplace learning that seek to isolate or manipulate a limited set of features to increase the probability of learning. Result.Title: Towards an emergent view of learning work

Result.Title: Researchers are learners too: collaboration in research on workplace learning

Result.Title: Talking up learning at work: Cautionary tales in co‐opting everyday learning

Result.Title: Confronting globalisation: learning from intercontinental collaboration

Result.Title: The Trigger Film: a Stimulus for Affective Learning

Result.Title: Assessing participation in discussion: An exploration of the issues

Result.Title: Rethinking models of feedback for learning: the challenge of design

Result.Title: Reconceptualising academic work as professional practice: implications for academic development

Result.Title: Re-thinking continuing professional development through changing metaphors and location in professional practices

Result.Title: Re-making Jobs: Enacting and Learning Work Practices

Result.Abstract: This paper takes up Schatzki (2005; 2006) understandings of organisations as 'bundles of practices' -work practices, and thus organisations, are both perpetuated and varied through employees' enactments of work. Using a practice lens and drawing data from two Australian organisations, we consider the ways workers simultaneously maintain and alter practices in their workplace. We characterise this as re-making one's job.
Result.Title: RE-MAKING JOBS: ENACTING AND LEARNING WORK PRACTICES

Result.Title: Creating a ‘world class’ programme: reciprocity and constraint in networked global collaboration
